items.description: Upper Bristol Avon area
items.message:
River levels are falling but remain high on the upper Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon and Dauntsey Brook. Flooding is possible through Thursday and into Friday.

Flooding may affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon and Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge.

We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue further Flood Alerts or Warnings if necessary. Drier conditions are expected for the remainder of the week and the situation should continue to improve.

Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 12/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Soar in Leicestershire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  
We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are high and rising slowly on the lower River Cherwell following recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 12/10/24, especially in the Heyford Bridge and Thrupp areas. Showers are forecast for this morning and afternoon. Sunday should be dry. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days and remain sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 13/10/24 ,or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are high but steady at the top end of the River Windrush, however lower down river levels are rising slowly as a result of recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 12/10/24 especially in the Bourton on the Water and Newbridge areas. Showers are forecast for this morning and afternoon. Sunday should be dry. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days and levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.
We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 13/10/24 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels remain high on the River Glyme although they are stabilising and starting to fall. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold on the River Evenlode. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 12/10/24, especially in the Woodstock area. Showers are forecast for this morning and afternoon. Sunday should be dry. River levels are expected to remain high on the River Glyme over the coming days. River levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.
We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 13/10/24 or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the River Thame following recent rainfall but river levels are falling upstream of Thame. Downstream of Thame river levels are still high and rising. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 12/10/24 especially in Thame, Stadhampton and Dorchester. Showers are forecast for this morning and afternoon. Sunday should be dry. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days and are sensitive to further rainfall.
We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 13/10/24 or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
Water levels have risen at the Sherborne Lake gauge on the River Yeo. Areas most at risk at this time are low-lying locations in the upper Yeo catchment around Sherborne. The River Wriggle and River Cam remain at normal winter levels, as does the River Yeo at Pen Mill. Property flooding is not expected.

The weather is forecast to remain largely dry over the weekend although isolated showers are possible.
 
 We are monitoring river levels closely. Please be careful using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions.

This message will be updated by 4PM on Saturday 12/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels are falling but remain responsive to further rainfall. This information is correct as of 07:30am on Saturday 12 October. There are currently no issues on the Earith causeway. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 41 centimetres of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 28 centimetres of water on the road. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways and Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the roads. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. We will update this message by 4pm today,12/10/2024.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels are high on the Lower River Colne and Frays River today, Friday 11th October.

No property flooding is expected, but flooding may continue to affect low lying land and roads, particularly in the Thorney Mill Road and Cricketfield Road areas, which may impact Riverside Mobile Home Park.

The forecast shows isolated light showers tomorrow, with levels starting to decrease on the Lower Colne at our Staines Moor river gauge. 

We are continuing to monitor rainfall and river levels and will remove this alert when the risk has reduced.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and monitor local water levels and weather conditions.

This message will be updated by 6pm tomorrow, Saturday 12th October, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

Showers are forecast for this morning and afternoon. Sunday should be dry.  River levels are expected to remain high for the next couple of days but continue falling slowly. River levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.
We are monitoring the situation.  Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 13/10/24 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Chertsey Bourne

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels continue to fall on the Chertsey Bourne. Therefore, the risk of further flooding of low lying land and roads in the Free Prae Road area of Chertsey is reducing. Outbreaks of rain are forecast this morning 12/10/24, before turning dry. River levels are slowly falling and we expect this to continue.  

Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 13/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Great Ouse in Cambridgeshire from Brampton to Earith
items.message:
River levels are now returning to normal. The forecast is for no significant rainfall for the next 4 days.

There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. 

We will continue to monitor levels closely and reissue flood warnings and alerts when necessary.

Showers are forecast for this morning and afternoon. Sunday should be dry. River levels are falling slowly and we expect this to continue but the river levels remain sensitive to further rainfall. We are monitoring the situation.  Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely to continue today, Saturday 12th October, and for at least the next 24hrs. Water levels continue to remain high, but are expected to soon start to drop back down to more normal levels. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message tomorrow morning, Sunday 13th October, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station is 7.94 m and falling slowly. The drain level is 7.23 m and steady. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this drain level exceeds 7.3 m.

We have commenced pumping at Huish Episcopi and Westover pumping stations and will continue to use the Parrett Relief Channel to further reduce river levels. We will maximise pumping operations to clear as much water off the moors as possible during this settled period.

The weather is forecast to be largely dry over the weekend although isolated showers are possible.

We continue to monitor the situation closely. Do not attempt to drive, cycle or walk through flood water, and be careful using footpaths near local watercourses and flooded areas. Refer to @TravelSomerset for local road closures.
 
This message will be updated by 4PM tomorrow, Saturday 12/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mid Bristol Avon area

items.message:
River levels remain high but are now falling on the middle Bristol Avon and Semington Brook. 

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Semington Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.

We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue further Flood Alerts or Warnings if necessary. Drier conditions are expected for the remainder of the week and the situation should continue to improve.

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 12/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Stour and tributaries

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Stour, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Wimborne and Christchurch.
Further rainfall is forecast this morning but no further flooding is expected.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 13/10/2024, or as the situation changes.
